Review_Text: Rodamon Hostel-Marrakech was more than we could have hoped for. An oasis in the middle of the old walled city of Marrakech. The hustle-bustle of the souk and Berber markets are right outside the door and inside you feel calm. The pool is refreshing the air conditioned rooms are beautiful and contain everything you need.  Our family of 3 stayed in a private room with a king bed and two bunk beds in a separate area; with a private bathroom and shower. Daily housekeeping similar to a hotel. The restaurant and bar on site are very convenient if you don‚Äôt want to venture out to the Medina for a meal. Review_Date: Heather W wrote a review Jan 2020

Review_Text: We just spent 5 nights at Rodamon Riad; it was an all round wonderful experience. This was our first visit to Marrakech so we had little idea what to expect the first surprise was that the Riad is right in the Medina Souk so foot access only - but it didn't matter at all we loved every minute of our time in Marrakech and Rodamon was excellent.  The property is beautifully maintained to a high standard; we had two superior double bedrooms both rooms were a very good size and the beds were super-king with fresh clean linen and very comfortable. There was not much storage for clothes a small closet to hang things in but no drawers so much of our stuff had to stay in our suitcases but this was OK for us because our room had lots of floor space it might be tougher in one of the standard or dorm rooms.  The bathrooms are on the small side but finished to a high standard and the showers are very good with no shortage of hot water and clean towels every day.  The roof terrace is lovely its a great place to sunbathe or just chill out in the afternoon especially after the hustle and bustle of the Souk.  The menu is very decent not exceptional but this is a Riad not a 5* hotel we were well catered for.  The one thing we hadn't bargained for is the cold; we were there in December and although by mid-afternoon the temperature in the sun was up to about 25 degrees in the shade it was cool and as any Riad is designed and built to stay cool it was never warmer than about 18 degrees within the building. We had A/C in our room so no problem with staying warm/cool at all but we were cold at breakfast time so if you go in winter take plenty of layers!  Finally the staff: I can't praise them enough they were endlessly friendly and helpful; we're reasonably self-sufficient and didn't need a ton of help from them but any time we did need anything they were right on it and every interaction was warm and friendly they are terrific.

Review_Date: Cristinejs wrote a review Apr 2019
Review_Text: We ended up in Marrakesh after 5 days in Morocco. We had heard that the city was very crazy and busy and that we probably wouldn't want to spend 3 days here but we are happy we did! Rodamon hostel was more like a resort hotel. It was very relaxing and very well situated in the Medina. Our beds were very nice and comfortable and the breakfast/ food was delicious. It was a great place to come back to and relax during the day. The only downside is that they have a strict night policy where you are not allowed to hang out in the common areas so when we would come back at like 11pm we would have to just go to bed. We did end up finding another hostel called Layla Rouge that had a super amazing rooftop patio and very relaxed staff that we ended up spending some time at to enjoy some chicha and the roof top sunset views. Also our room was VERY hot at night and we were there in April so if you are travelling in the summer you may find it to be even more hot. I believe they do have air conditioning in the rooms though but I did not check or ask.    Overall a beautiful spot to enjoy and relax! Would definitely go back and would recommend to others.

Review_Date: tomalley4 wrote a review Jan 2019
Review_Text: We stayed here for two nights. The first in dorm rooms (because private rooms were sold out) and the second night in a private room. I very rarely complain about places I stay but there were a few points I was not happy with about Rodamon Riad Hostel. Firstly beforehand we booked two beds in the same dorm room however upon arrival we were told that a larger party had arrived and they accomdated them and changed our booking so we were in two separate dorm rooms. This wouldn‚Äôt have been so bad but my girlfriend was spending her first night in a dorm room and was slightly nervous. Throughout the night the noise travels around the hostel and you can hear every door that is slammed. The breakfast in the morning was reasonable and ok but some of the buffet items ran out and took a while to be replaced. On the second night in our private room it was a good size. However the shower was blocked and kept flooding so we could not even shower before we had to fly home. All in all it is a nice looking hostel but I feel this is at the expense of the basic requirements of a place to stay. The location is good and you can get a beer here which is useful but it overpriced for what you get. It is ashame because I was really looking forward to staying here and it could be a great hostel but we did not have a good experience.

Review_Date: Aqeel wrote a review Aug 2018
Review_Title: A relaxing haven inside the crazy madina
Review_Text: If you're like me the first thing you do before you book somewhere is read review after review to find a regular theme of either good or bad and then make a decision.    That's exactly what I did with Riad rodam√≥n and with the very small amount of negative reviews it was not enough to put me off and if I'm honest i do not see how this place can get any negative reviews.    I'm going to make this simple if you want to experience the madina and culture of true Marrakech but also want to balance this with relaxation and clean environment then this is the place to be.    The Riad is within walking distance of the main square Jemaa el-Fnaa and there are a few shops/huts near by that you can buy water drinks and snacks to take back to the hostel.    The riad itself is the most clean and beautiful hostel I've ever stayed at. I booked a superior double private room for my stay different from my normal shared dorm because of the reasonable price. The room was amazing with Moroccan style decor and AC for the boiling heat during August.    The roof terrace is such a cool place to relax catch some rays and hangout with friends or meet new people. The only thing that it didn't provide is the view as it suggests due the walls being high but that was very minor because you could see a beautiful sunset.    The pool area is amazing and relaxing with its garden style feel and water fountain feature sending you in to a zen state of mind. The pool itself may not be huge but it was a good size to cool off and hang with new people to talk to.    The staff there are the most helpful and polite who will go out there way to make sure your stay is everything you need. They help with taxis tours or guide you to where you need to go.    They also offer a nice food selection for the evening but limited during the day regardless still delicious.    I would 100% come back to this riad. The value for money the location cleanliness customer service and relaxing vibes is everything you need.    Oh and for any bloggers this is a heaven place for you to take pictures!    Thank you to all the staff there!

Review_Date: Canadaian_G wrote a review Aug 2018
Review_Title: Great Hostel but Be Prepared to Be Harassed!
Review_Text: This is a fantastic hostel one of the most beautiful I've visited. The photos don't lie. The staff is also excellent the rooms are clean and the place is just stunning.    The only problem is the location. The hostel is deep deep deep in the Medina making it a nightmare to find. After dark it's easy to get trapped in the closed souk where a local teenager will approach you and try to show you the way out. He'll then shake you down for money and not in a polite "can I have a tip please" sort of way. Felt more like assault. This happened to my friends and I on 3 separate occasions over 2 days. It was a common story among many of the travellers staying at Rodamon. The staff seemed well aware. It can be a very frightening experience for younger or single travellers. One fellow in my dorm was shaken down for a total of 800 dirhams in one day (about 80 euro) the moment he stepped out of Rodamon.    Friends at other hostels did not have this problem. Be very careful staying here.

Review_Date: Hlen wrote a review Jun 2018
Review_Title: A Word of Warning: Rodamon is Not a Safe Space
Review_Text: Warning: Victim-shaming racial bias and prejudice.    I'm sure this is a rare case in all hostels but my roommate was a racist. She held preconceived opinions about my identity. She made unwarranted remarks about my nationality ethnicity the way I spoke and even my hairstyle even though I was barely in the shared room. Her condescending remarks eventually escalated in her grabbing my throat and digging her fingernails into my neck. I found out later that the night before when she had caused a scene at 2:30 am about the air conditioning she had tried to attack me but the security had stopped her. At the time she told the manager that everything was my fault and he seemed to buy it while I was frozen because I felt traumatized.    I spoke to the manager the following day after the attack ‚Äì when I had finally digested most of the situation it took a very long time to get him to empathize or at least sympathize. Finally a staff member explained to him that the woman was indeed racist. He took some action and assured me he has blacklisted her (I cannot confirm at this moment if that is true).    I truly felt that the situation could have been handled better. I was told I could have called the police or spoke up the night of the attack but I was traumatized by the event. I felt that the management did not know how to properly deal with situations like mine. I was sent straight to my new room no tea no water nothing was done to help me come down from my trauma. In fact it sounded like the whole situation was assumed rather than investigated.    They promised me an emailed formal apology and proof that the woman is blacklisted. But has yet to send me any of this information.    ***** So if you're a traveller looking for a safe space and a place that can help you when worse comes to worse in a foreign place ‚Äì I would not suggest going to Rodamon hostels. They are not trained to deal with guests who a prejudice given that there seem to be no policies in place on investigating situations fairly.    It is your basic level hostel and it is very photogenic. It will do the job as long as the worst case scenario does not happen to you ‚Äì which I hope it does not.    Overall I would say be warned. They will not call the police for you if you are in trouble. They will not help you feel safe at the hostel. They will not comfort you if you are distressed - I've been to a few hostels that I've seen do so and you're better off investing your money in that type of hostel.    Furthermore their wifi is quite unreliable even though they had 3 different routers.

Review_Date: Brogan J wrote a review Mar 2018
Review_Text: After walking the dusty dirty medina looking for the place I couldn't believe what I'd walked into. Gorgeous from top to bottom. Plenty of common space spread out over four floors a terrace with day beds a small pool amongst a courtyard of Islamic tilework a bar a top breakfast. Staff were incredibly friendly and helpful. Dorms weren't all that spacious though the beds were comfortable and had individual power sockets and reading lights. My three-night stay was only 33 euros. One downside - a bit difficult to find - but that's the problem with everything in the medina.

Review_Date: GrizzyCDG wrote a review Feb 2018
Review_Text: This was our first trip to Marrakech so we have contacted the Hostel prior our arrival to arrange transport which we think it is necessary so you can avoid high prices with cabs outside the airport.    The transfer stops 2 min walking from the Hostel because it is located in a small street and can not enter.    Once in there we have been welcomed by Ilham and Simo special thanks to these two for helping us with a smooth in and out recommending places to visit and also to eat.. "El Haj Moustafa it's a must" they have the best meat we had in our lives.    For couples we recommend the superior room it is perfect enough space closet huge bed really nice typical moroccan bathroom and A/c-Heater.    If it's sunny which is most of the time in Marrakech you have the swimming pool in the ground floor or the rooftop terrace which is perfect for chilling having a drink chit chatting with other travelers and having fun.    One night we had dinner in the restaurant and it was very delicious and the plates were pretty big we recommend to try it at least once during your stay.    I have to say that for the price they offer we couldn't find anything better in the city because we had plenty of things to do in the main hostel also.    Last but not least a huge thank you to Jordi the Hostel Manager for taking care of all the details he was up to everything we needed and this kind of service can not be found anywhere.    Expect us we are coming back.  Munir & Manal

Review_Date: Natalie Curro wrote a review Feb 2018

Review_Date: charliegum wrote a review Jan 2018
Review_Title: The best hostel you will ever stay in!!
Review_Text: The hostel is stunningly beautiful but the staff make this hostel so so extra special. Simo and Ilham are some of the best people you will ever meet - they made me feel so at home helped with anything I needed and were just so friendly fun and lovely.    The hostel is also obviously beautiful. It is a very friendly fun hostel feel to it with a great atmosphere that makes it easy to make friends as a solo traveller or even as friends/couples travelling together but it is in the setting of a beautiful Moroccan Riad. It is so stunning it is just like one of the expensive boutique hotels around but better!    The dorm rooms are lovely the beds are comfy and have curtains on them so you can have privacy/block out the lights and each bed has it's own cute little Moroccan shelf with a lamp and a plug socket in it! The bathrooms in the dorm rooms were also BEAUTIFUL. The private rooms also looked so beautiful like amazing hotel rooms.    The food and bar was also great! The man Salah on the bar was a sweetheart and was always smiling and friendly. The staff also organised a transfer for me from the airport (for just ¬£10) which was great and saved me lots of hassle! Also Hamza should get a mention because he was super nice too :) and the breakfast was amazing and the girl who tended to the breakfast was really sweet! I was also a bit sick with a cold and all the staff looked after me giving me boiling water whenever I needed it and generally being lovely.    Also the Medina (old city) of Marrakech is a maze but there are signs all over pointing the way to Rodamon Riad - which is sooo helpful!

Review_Date: Capres T wrote a review Jan 2018
Review_Title: Safe Haven in the midst of a Crazy City
Review_Text: This Riad is very stunning and the staff are just wonderful. From the moment you arrive (after tackling the crazy souks) you are greeted with smiling faces clean surroundings and a comfy bed. I stayed in one of the female only dorm rooms and was very very pleased with the value for money. This Riad surpassed my expectations completely. The breakfast was good and even on the morning of my departure before breakfast had started there was coffee and cake available for a morning kick. I saw many people taking pictures of the interior and exterior of the building as it is beautiful to look at and maintained to a high standard. Also sometimes staying in Morocco bed bugs can be a problem but whilst here this did not cross my mind at all! This place is absolutely spotless!    Sadly the only negative I have to write about is the location. It is in the absolute heart of the Medina -Old Town- which seems wonderful at first...you have to weave your way through the bustling souks to find the small safe haven which is very exciting. The problem is some of the local people of Marrakech (I do not wish to generalise) do sadly see tourists as ATM machines and you are liable to become victim to scams/robbery/assault if you plan to visit the night market/explore after sunset. I have discussed this with the staff and I'm sure they are very tired of having the same conversations about this. It is a real shame as the country is very beautiful and this Riad is so so so lovely but beware (I was a solo female traveller) and often did not feel safe until I was inside the Rodamon walls!

Review_Date: Sami K wrote a review Jan 2018
Review_Text: While booking this hostel I thought that the pictures shown here were too good to be real. When I arrived I was surprised how clean and modern the hostel is. It has a nice pool for warm days and a very beautiful terrace on the rooftop.  What I liked the most was the very warmhearted staff. Every staff member was ready to help me and answer my questions concerning the city or the hostel. Especially the staff member Sidi Mohamed was very caring. Even after work he was ready to show me and other hostel guests the city and other nice places which I wouldn't have discovered if he wasn't there. After 10 days at the hostel with the well caring and funny staff the location felt like home and I'll certainly come back soon to this place!  Simo I hope you'll be there when I'm coming back! Thank you for everything!

Review_Date: Michelange M wrote a review Jan 2018

Review_Date: Nolene F wrote a review Nov 2017
Review_Text: I loved my stay at this riad. I chose a shared 4 bed female room but was the only one in the room for my 4 nights. The room had good space nicely decorated and had ac and good wifi.    The breakfast is good and they have a menu that has some basic eats for lunch and dinner. They are very close to a bunch of nice restaurants. They serve alcohol which is not hugely common in this muslim country. Nice roof deck for the evening.    The staff was great and helped me find a place down the road for laundry and arranged my transport to airport my last day.    It is about 0.5-0.7 mi from djemaa el fna and although easy to find the square not always easy to find your way back . Even taxi drivers had trouble finding it. By my last day I was kind of getting my bearings but admit I got lost twice trying to get back to my riad.
